headline.main: Budget Talks Going Down To the Wire At City Hall

docs.abstract: Giuliani administration and City Council try to reach agreement on cutbacks to New York City programs that could help close projected budget gap of more than $1 billion for fiscal year ending June 30; Councilman Herbert E Berman says talks will likely continue into night before Council's final voting session; Council leader Peter Vallone is anxious for deal as he leaves office (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As night fell over City Hall yesterday, officials were still negotiating over the city's budget, unsure whether they would reach an agreement before the final voting session of the City Council, scheduled for today. Giuliani administration officials and Council officials were trying to reach agreement on cutbacks in city programs that could help close a projected budget gap of more than $1 billion for the fiscal year ending June 30. At issue are the depth of cutbacks in items like day care slots or AIDS prevention plans, or the hours at libraries and parks services.
docs.snippet: As night fell over City Hall yesterday, officials were still negotiating over the city's budget, unsure whether they would reach an agreement before the final voting session of the City Council, scheduled for today.    Giuliani administration...

docs.abstract: Sheldon J Binn letter comments on Dec 11 article on lung cancer that killed George Harrison, a smoker
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The column ''An Old Enemy, Smoking, Hangs Tough'' suggests syllogistically that George Harrison smoked; therefore, he died of cancer. If a person swallows potassium cyanide and dies, the cause-and-effect conclusion is obvious and valid. If a person falls 86 stories and dies, the cause and effect speak for themselves. There is indeed a probability relationship between smoking and cancer, but it is not a ''certainty'' -- not cause and effect like cyanide poisoning.

headline.main: After Two-Decade Halt, Marijuana Research Is Set

docs.abstract: Research on medical uses of marijuana is scheduled to begin early next year, for first time in nearly two decades; government has approved new experiments to test whether drug can help patients who have multiple sclerosis or who suffer from pain in their limbs as result of AIDS; new approvals granted by Drug Enforcement Administration do not make it legal for doctors to give their patient marijuana; they merely provided for limited use in scientific experiments, which will be conducted by Center for Medicinal Cannabis Research run by University of California (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Research on the medical uses of marijuana is scheduled to begin early next year, for the first time in nearly two decades, now that the government has approved new experiments to test whether smoking it can help patients who have multiple sclerosis or who suffer from pain in their limbs as a result of AIDS. The new approvals, granted on Nov. 28 by the Drug Enforcement Administration, do not make it legal for doctors to give their patients marijuana as treatment; they merely provide for limited use in scientific experiments. In some states, state law allows doctors to prescribe or recommend marijuana; federal law prohibits the practice, however, even in those states.
docs.snippet: Research on the medical uses of marijuana is scheduled to begin early next year, for the first time in nearly two decades, now that the government has approved new experiments to test whether smoking it can help patients who have multiple sclerosis...
